channel.title: Matt Dailey's Writing
channel.description: Things I thought were worth writing down.

item.title: Legacy
item.description: We were in a medium-loud public setting at a long high-top table and I was explaining how life changed after having kids to a friend without kids. I told them I'd never cared about the idea of "legacy" but I get it now holding my children and realizing that they are the only things I've created or will ever create that will go on beyond me.
item.author: matt@reactiverobot.com (Matt Dailey)

item.title: Burnout happens
item.author: matt@reactiverobot.com (Matt Dailey)
item.description: I love long road trips and letting my thoughts drift while I drive. It can be really creative and energizing, and I often ask my wife to jot down an idea and text it to me so I don't lose it. But sometimes my thoughts drift into rough waters. I get stuck on something and start turning it over and over in my mind, getting more and more worked up.

item.title: Hiring is emotional
item.description: When I'm stressed about work, I pace around the house. I work in our bedroom so I walk back and forth at the foot of the bed. My pacing is a mix of silent rehearsal and fist pumping to psych myself up. But for one call in winter 2022, I struggled to get in the zone.
item.author: matt@reactiverobot.com (Matt Dailey)

item.title: Code review is your job
item.description: When I started at Palantir, my desk was in a typical Silicon Valley office space. My team was in a room with six standing desks, no windows and a huge purple bean bag in the corner. I came back to my desk one afternoon feeling pretty good. I had just sent one my first decently large PRs for review and I was proud of it.
item.author: matt@reactiverobot.com (Matt Dailey)

item.title: Always be pitching
item.description: While managing the Growth team at Figma, I worked from home in a small, downstairs one-bedroom with two rooms. I worked in the bedroom and my wife Courtney worked in the everything-else room.
item.author: matt@reactiverobot.com (Matt Dailey)

item.title: Only outcomes matter
item.description: When I joined Figma, it was small enough for me to set up a coffee date with every employee. Everyone sat in a big room above a bar and coffee shop so every day for my first two months, I’d grab someone and go to the coffee stand downstairs to get to know them.
item.author: matt@reactiverobot.com (Matt Dailey)

item.title: Leveling up hurts
item.description: I quit the startup before Figma after just 3 months. It's not on my LinkedIn so you can't look it up. It wasn't the right role for me but I went for it, partly due to the higher pay. They offered way more than I made previously, which turned out to be pretty unfortunate.
item.author: matt@reactiverobot.com (Matt Dailey)

item.title: Reflection is all you need
item.description: Story of when I met my favorite meeting and the importance of reflection.
item.author: matt@reactiverobot.com (Matt Dailey)

item.title: I want you to f-ing get it
item.author: matt@reactiverobot.com (Matt Dailey)
item.description: In spring 2016, I worked at a seed stage start-up called “Radical Candor,” founded by Kim Scott and Russ Laraway to build software to help managers become better managers. Everyday I coded in the back seat of a Lyft on Highway 280 as I rode to our office in the Flintstone House, 45 minutes south of San Francisco.
